question.text: Which of these relations between two partial pressures is incorrect?

options.text: <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>  in atmospheric air   <math><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>  in alveoli

<math><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> in oxygenated blood <math><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> in deoxygenated blood

<math><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>  in oxygenated blood  <math><mo><</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>  in tissues

solution.text:
The various partial pressures in the respiratory system are tabulated as follows:



pO2 in atmospheric air is 159 mm Hg while pO2 in alveoli is 104 mm Hg. pCO2 in oxygenated blood is 40 mm Hg while pO2 in deoxygenated blood is 40 mm Hg. pCO2 in oxygenated blood is 40 mm Hg while pCO2 in tissues 45 mm Hg. pO2 in alveoli is 104 mm Hg and pO2 in oxygenated blood is 95 mm Hg. These values are not equal
